description.text: A pen to hold a standard gel ink rollerball cartridge, designed to replace a defunct fountain pen assembly in a pen I got on vacation

When I was on vacation, I got a really nice looking fountain pen. Unfortunately, the innards were junk - every time I put a new ink cartridge in it, it would dry out and die.
The solution was to design a custom pen tip that screwed into the barrel the same way, had the same retaining collar to hold the pen cap on - but instead housed a standard gel-ink rollerball cartridge.

title: Creality CR-10 LCD Cover for Overnight Printing

description.text:
This Thing is an adapted version of my Anet A6 LCD Cover found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1926802

This slip-on LCD Screen Cover allows you to print overnight without the blinding effects of the CR-10 screen illuminating the entire room. This was a problem for me because, due to the limited space of my 3-person apartment, my printer is housed in my bedroom. The cover also conveniently fits on top of your control box when not in use while leaving the USB and Micro SD ports accessible.

I have included two models: a blank cover and a cover embossed with my initials for concept proof. Feel free to download the .step files and upload a remix as you wish. Just please remember to attribute. I'd love to see the awesome designs that could come out of this.

When using 15% infill, a slight amount of light allows the cover to have a subtle glow. This gives a pretty neat lithophane effect. The amount of light that shows through can obviously be altered by increasing infill or using a darker color filament, although the setup in which I printed doesn't allow enough light through to even notice.

For printing with no supports and optimal light blocking, position the cover upside down on the print bed so the control knob cutout is facing upwards. This orients the infill parallel to the screen and perpendicular to the emitted light.

title: Match box with holes for magnets

description.text: This is a small sliding matchbox. It is approximately 30mm x 40mm x 65mm. I designed it in Tinkercad to hold guitar picks. I added rare earth magnets to the bottom to stick it to a metal music stand. It is fun to add designs or names of bandmates etc... It prints easily and takes about 31/2 hours using fine (.2mm) resolution and 20% infill. It requires about 45 grams of filament. I used standard settings in Cura with a 200 degree nozzle and 60 degree bed temps in Celsius. I printed this in PLA. It cleans up easily and works well with just a little tweaking to make it slide well.

I used the fine printer settings in Cura with 20% infill. The nozzle was 200 degrees Celsius and the bed was 60 degrees Celsius. I printed with PLA.
This box works well with just a little post printing clean-up. The inner part is slightly smaller for a snug but sliding fit.

I designed this box in Tinkercad and use it as a guitar pick holder. I added 8mm holes in the bottom which are 2mm deep for rare earth magnets. I heat up the magnets with a heat gun and press them into the holes for a great fit.

This was just a quick shot at an external gear pump, I wondered if it was actually possible to make a working water pump. It works, doesn't leak, and I'm actually really happy with the result.

Supports:

No

Notes:

Print the gasket with the most flexible material, if not available, seal it any other way.
Use the file gear if your printer isn't capable of good tolerances, use the file gear_tight if it is (any machine above $300 should be able to do that). There are two housings to choose from, the _mount file has two mounting holes, whereas the regular one is just a unit.

Assembly

To assemble this pump, you'll ned a couple more things: a 2mm shaft, rubber band, an electric motor or whatever to power it with (has to have a 2mm shaft, might have to do some coupling) and some grease. Print out every part according to aforementioned settings. Take a 2mm drill and drill one of the gears. Then take a 2.2mm drill and drill out the other one. The gear with a bigger hole will be the idler gear. Then take the shaft and cut 15mm off of it. That will be the idler shaft. Next up, it press fit the drive gear onto your drive shaft so that about 2mm of the shaft is protruding. Insert both gears into the housing. Now, take some grease and put a dab of it into the cutout on the drive shaft hole. Using a piece of a rubber band, seal the drive shaft. Take the printed gasket and put it in place. Cover it with the remaining part and screw it together using either M3 screws and a nut, or in my case, use an M3 threaded rod and a nut on each side. That's it, now just hook up your hose and you're good to go. Hose opening is 6mm in diameter.

3D Print of the Fab Lab Logo. Created this for the recently approved Fab Lab at our school.
https://www.fablabs.io/labs/saintpaulsfablab

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Resolution:

Notes:

Print 3 of the segment files individually in blue, red, and green. Print the base in white. Resize or print any colors you like!

Assembly

Glue the segments onto the base with hot glue, CA, or modeling cement.

Design Story

Started with an SVG file of the Fab Lab logo available at: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Fab_Lab_logo.svg
Inserted the SVG file into a new design in Fusion 360 and extruded one segment of the sketch 10mm. Filleted all the edges 1mm. Selected segment to output to 3D printing.
Measured the diameter of the logo and created a base the same diameter 5mm thick.

Each amc7135 chip on this board supplies 350mA. The board will supply 2+amps, so one must desolder a couple of these 7135 chips, taking it down to the prefered maximum amp draw. The momentary switches are connected in parallel with the on board switch.

Driver base hooks to harness, driver base also uses paracord to secure base to white led housing. Cord is threaded through the holes, and then melted at the end making it unable to come loose. Features independant control of white and red leds, 4 brightness modes, as well as sos, flash. Uses nitecore F1 18650 powerbank, which is rated at a 1amp output. Both battery and powerbank have protection circuits for safety of the dog, as this design is NOT WATERPROOF, and shouldn't be used in the rain or anywhere it could get water on it.

The white led driver is set at 700mA current limit, and the red is set to 350mA current limit giving a total of 1050mA current draw when both sets of leds are at maximum brightness. I have used a thermal imager and the heatsinked driver boards, and heatsinked leds remain at a safe temperature. All parts were made with t-glase, although, abs or a more flexible filament might be the optimal choice for the buckle clips.

description.text:
This is a remix of the x belt attachment which I like most by Simhopp with a better belt fit. The belt attachment by Simhopp is a really nice design, but I lost the belt during printing. After that I used glue for a second try, but after a few prints I lost the belt again. This is the reason why I remixed it. In different to the original design, I shrink the dimensions of the belt holder. With this remix you never lost the belt also without glue. Press the belt into the rabbet by using a flat screwdriver and you are done.

You will need six M3x18 screws for mounting the part properly to the printer.

description.text:
This is a housing for a high-mounted 3rd brake light which can be fitted into a Fiat (or Bertone) X1/9. Early 80's and 70's models did not have this feature.

This light is designed to accommodate a 12V LED strip (there are several on eBay. The housing can be affixed to the trim molding above the rear glass with 3M double stick tape and is very low profile. You'll need to run a ground and +12v brake wire up through the targa top and to the brake light to make it work. See photos of the printed part and the final version which was painted and installed in my X1/9.

description.text:
I thought I'd be fun to do a project with my 8 yo daughter and involve her in the design process. She drew this on paper and I traced it (and made the design work) in Fusion 360.
I strongly recommend going this with your kids. Not only is it fun, a great way to share and pass on your hobby, but it's also a great way for them to learn spatial problem solving, through design.

Either way, it's a quick print and we hope some of you will enjoy to make your own.

B.O.M.:
The only thing you need to make, other than a 3d printer, is 4 608ZZ ball bearings. You can pick these up at any local skate shop or from ebay, I recommend spending a little extra on the center bearing and getting a ceramic one. These will run very smooth and long. I also recommend removing any grease from the center bearing using a solvent like WD40 og terpentine, again this makes for less friction and longer spintimes.

UPDATE- I made changes to the mounting tabs on both standard and extended hoppers. so they fit a little better.

This hopper will allow you to dispense anything granular from a drone. This particular hopper is designed for the DJI S1000. It can be used for fire ant poison or fertilizer application.
You will need a continuous rotation servo to drive the auger. in my case i used a HItec HS-645MG metal gear servo. I converted it to continuous rotation. You can follow this simple tutorial here to do it yourself http://www.instructables.com/id/Converting-Micro-Servos-for-Continuous-Rotation/.
The servo horn will need to be trimmed to fit the auger dogs. You can see this in the pictures.

I am using a Arduino nano for accurate and repeatable dispenses. you can just plug the servo directly to the receiver if you wanted to operate it manually.

description.text:
Drone platform for 12inch props. Designed with the maker and developer in mind.

Recommended hardware:

  • 12 inch props
  • motors between 800kv to 500kv with a 19 mm & 25mm bolt tie down pattern (tested with 650kv MT3506 T-Motor)
  • small 36mm x 36mm flight controller (tested with Flip32)
  • 4 in one 36mm x 36mm electronic speed controller (tested with Favourite 20Ax4)
  • small 25mw VTX with fixed antena mount (tested with Foxeer TM25)
  • small FPV camera (tested with Foxeer Arrow V1)
  • VTX antena
  • 30mm length x 5mm diameter round aluminum standoffs inserted inside motor arms. Place a screw to absorb impact when hammering the standoff inside the motor arm.
  • steel screws to hold motors and center plates (6mm recommended thread length)
  • two 4s 1300mah lipos

Motor boom printing recommendations:

-Setting low infill values will make the booms lightweight as carbon fiber counterparts or maybe lighter. Unfortunately this will sacrifice strength. On the other hand setting higher values will make it stronger but heavier. I tested this legs with 50% infill and 1mm wall thickness they weighted the same as DJI flame wheel cousins and withstood minor 20ft crash landings.

  • To print without supports or rafts print with the flat side towards printing bed.
  • PLA is ok material ABS is the go to.
  • Depending on the calibration of the 3d printer minor modifications may be needed for the standoff inserts.

CNC recommendations center plates:

  • I tested with 2mm thickness carbon fiber cutting it with a 3mm router bit. If it is your first time cutting carbon fiber go slow with the feed rate. Cut depth should be half of the diameter of the tool. I was able to achieve this cut with a GEN 1 Shapeoko in 30 minutes (SUPER SLOW so the steppers motors would not skip a line). On a more profesional machine such as a Laguna Tool you will have a superb cut piece in as little as 5 minutes.

Dimensions:

  • All the files are in mm

title: Fast Change Effector Wiring Connector Holder

description.text: A holder for 2 "Aviation" connectors and tubing connection to make the wiring for effector and extruder quick change. It mounts on 2020 extrusion. Designed for my delta so I can quick change between effectors with a direct drive stepper and Zesty Nimble cable drive, or from 1.75 mm to 3mm filament. I included a hole and landing for Berd-Air style cooling tubing. The tubing from the pump to the box will fit snugly over the landing inside and the smaller tubing to the effector fits on a piece of #10 hypodermic tubing. I always design holes that are accessible a little small to allow final sizing with number bits. I drilled the hole to a #30 size and with the hypodermic tubing in a drill friction welded it into the hole. The material I used is PETG and this must be done quickly and without stopping until it is at the depth you want. I am going to use 2 different "Aviation" connectors, one with 9 pins and one with 10 pins so they cannot be accidentally interchanged. The connectors I got are rated for 5 amps per pin which will be fine for a 12V or 24V hot end heater, but some connectors are only rated for 3 amps max and at 12V would not be suitable. The ones I got are from ebay seller giorgio11185
Designed with Onshape

description.text:
Tout le monde a fait le sien alors pourquoi pas moi :P

N'ayant pas encore imprimé toutes les pièces du mod de Bezain, je commence par un petit add-on perso pour la DiscoEasy. Un anti-wobble avec un roulement à bille pour éviter d'usiner la pièce à force de tourner dedans.

Roulement standard :

  • diam intérieur : 8mm
  • diam extérieur : 22mm
  • hauteur : 7 mm

S'imprime nikel en 0.2mm, avec support.

Printer:

Dagoma DiscoEasy200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

ne pas avaler car difficile à digérer, beuark !

comments.text:
Pour qu'il n'y ait pas de contrainte sur les moteurs il faut monter les tiges filetés dans le roulement, puis dans le coupleur, et ensuite serrer les coupleurs sur les moteurs.
Par contre, si les tiges filetées sont trop courbées, monter cette pièce rajoutera du wobble ! Dans tous les cas, il faut que l'écrou qui fait monter le chariot de l'axe X soit le plus libre possible sur le plan horizontal.
comments.author: tibrol

comments.text: Imprimé et installé, c’est mieu que les pièces plastique 1er generation. Niveau bruit c’est pas pire qu’avant. Bon boulot

Perso, cela fait des contraintes sur les moteurs, et beaucoup de bruit.
Mais l'idée est bonne.

title: Differential IR Fan and sensor mount

description.text:
My hotend mount to the extractor requires my hotend fan (40mm) to be somewhat different than most designs as I remixed Andy Carrs and Maso27 original designs. This fan mount for a silent 40mm fan also includes a mount for DC47s differential IR sensor.

I did not have much luck with the sensor though, so now I am running with a Geeetech 3Dtouch and I am very pleased.

print_settings.Notes:: Print at 1.5% scale for most convenience

description.text:
Sometimes bees appear dead, but they are in fact just tired and dehydrated.
You can revive them by giving them a solution of sugar water.

"To create this energy drink for bees to revive tired bees, The RSPB suggest mixing two tablespoons of white, granulated sugar with one tablespoon of water, and placing the mix on a plate or spoon. Do not add any more water otherwise the bee could drown."

  • http://moralfibres.co.uk/how-to-revive-tired-bees/

You can prepare a beefree hydrator with sugar solution and cover it with cling film (sandwich wrap) to carry in your pocket or bag, ready to revive a poor thirsty bee if you happen to come across one.

The design of the hydrator includes a ramp to make it easier to slide under a bee

title: Hearts Spinner for Kids
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a small spinner for kids hands. For my daughter (5 years old) it fits perfect. Sure the spinning time ins´t so long as with usual spinners. But the fun factor is the same ;o)
The total diameter is 60mm.
It depends of two halfs, 6 heart inlays, 2 finger tips, 6 M5 nuts and one 625 bearing.
The small red hearts fit perfectly without gluing. After assembling I glued both parts with superglue and fixed it for a while with a clamp.

Raptile Clone

No

0.2mm

25%

author: SteBoo

title: Watering bowl for danish soda bottles

description.text:
I needed a water dispenser with a very small surface to avoid to much vaporization during the summer period. I did this watering bowl from scratch by designing a threaded hole that matches most Danish soda bottles. And made it possible to hang it on the wall - hens drink in a very special way so they need it a bit up from the ground.

Printed in PLA with 4 perimeters and 5 top and bottom layers to make it watertight.

title: Dr Who Time Expander Opto Cover

description.text:
The Dr Who pinball machine uses a #03-8655 Bally/Williams plastic base. The opto sensors are susceptible to light contamination from both outside the mechanism and inside. This resolves it once and for all.

Does replace the paper light shield.

Does not replace 03-8655, but instead fits inside it with a friction fit. Completely disassemble mechanism before installing.

Recommended: black filament, 98% infill, ABS material

title: Hailong E-bike battery adapter for Gazelle Orange (Pure)

description.text:
This is an adapter for the China Hailong e-bike Battery case made to fit the Dutch Gazelle Orange Pure bike.

I did not want to drill 2 extra holes in my frame to fit 2 M5 rivet nuts as I want to keep the setup upgradable in both battery and bike aspect.
I decided to create an adapter that uses Zip-ties to the top of the down tube and 2 bolts to the bottle holder on the frame. the shape of the adapter keeps it from moving and creating excess force on the original bottle holder nuts.

The bike frame was scanned with a iSense scanner to make it fit snugly

I created an adapter with a space inside to hide all electronics (250W 36V) and cables (motor and PAS) to make it a clean looking install, and an adapter if you want to use the original provided electronics box.

it uses Stainless M5 screws (2 cilinder head for the Bottle holder mounts, 2 flat head for the battery mount) and 2 Stainless M5 nuts to secure the battery at the top leaving 3 mounting points on the battery itself. 2 bolts to the frame, and 2 large zip-ties on the frame at the top to prevent excess force.

The ESC box version has a bleeder hole to let out water from rain and condensation.

In the end, I printed both, and used the one without electronics box incorporated as my Electronics had pre-made weatherproof cables that were too long to fit inside the box. The wires now run along the horizontal tube to the provided box on the vertical frame so that I do not have to cut wires.
If you do not have the EUNORAU KIT but a kit with a bunch of wires coming out of the speed controller use the one with electronics box incorporated for a clean install.

Creality CR-10

title: Quick release star knob (M8)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a quick release star knop for M8 threaded rods. I use it to fix my filament spools. So it is easy to change them.
How it works: The knob has a concentric and vertical M8 thread. Under an angle of 12° to the M8 axis is a 8.5mm bore-hole.
If you tilt the knob on the rod you can easily push the knob through the thread. When in position, bring the knob into a straight position. Then you can fix your part by turning the knob.

author: akifex

description.text:
Aku Aku from Crash Bandicoot

The model was made by me based on some pics I have found online.

We 3D printed this thing and now is the trophy for a Crash Team Racing Tournament.

Hope you like it!
3D printed and painted

If you see lots of fidget spinners on the fotos: Congratulations -- maeeep -- wrong!

The objects here are simple wooden toys cut from 3mm plywood with a lasercutter. (Yeah, the center hole is only there to fool those fidget spinner addicts.) The pieces tile the plane and can be cut with very little waste. The pieces connect to each other in a zig-zag way, and 8 pieces form a ring. This is not mathematically perfect, but as it is wood, it easily bends inwards to close the ring. Or 10 pieces form a ring if bent outwards.

Two rings can be connected by additional 4 pieces to form a cube (or a pentagonal box).

Stacked cubes form columns. Columns can be connected in 90 deg. angles.
An arc (or a complete large 10 sided regular polygon) can be formed, if short columns of cubes are connected with 5 sided boxes in regular intervals.

The svg file also has a layer containing 4 headed tiles. Those are intended to create useful strings of tiles, which is not possible with the 3 headed tiles.

Mathematical properties These geometric structures can be seen, when playing with dreikopftile:
  • Triangle: The basic tile is a triangle.
  • Square: a tight 'ring' of 8 tiles has 4 distinct corners.
  • Pentagon: a widened ring of 10 tiles has 5 distinct corners.
  • Hexagon: a cube viewed diagonally is a hexagonal structure. The basic tile has 6 corners. They form a regular hexagon.
    • In scientific research presented at http://www.theorie1.physik.fau.de/people/skapfer/index.html a very similar design is classified as quasicrystals: "Quasicrystals include additional degrees of freedom (phasons) over the ones known from periodic crystals (phonons). How these lead to new kinds of topological defects is currently being investigated" -- I can confirm that there are sometime topological defects if the plywood snaps, when you try to bend it into rings of 8 or 10. But that is probably not what the research is about.... The relation to http://www.theorie1.physik.fau.de/people/skapfer/media/dodeca-qc-tiles.ps not fully understood. Maybe it is a remix? :-)

title: Creality CR-10 Spool Adapter - Large and Small

description.text:
The available spool adapters for the CR-10 didn't meet my needs, so I designed a few of my own. Two sizes are available: 70mm diameter and 90mm diameter. 90mm diameter works perfectly for Tiny Machines' filament, which has a massive inner diameter.

I have optimized the pitch of the threads so that they print smoothly without the need for support, and they are coarse enough so the "bolt" and "nut" thread together with fewer twists.

As for any sort of play or "slop" in the threads, I iterated several times to find a fit that is both easy to thread and a firm connection at the same time. The tolerance of the nut and bolt is 0.3mm, so depending on your printer, you may need to scale up the NUT by 1-2% to suit your needs. DO NOT scale down the bolt, as it could cause the inner diameter to become too small and will not fit on the control box spool holder.

title: Trailer Hitch Cover, Parametric with optional text

description.text:
This is a trailer hitch cover. It can be completely customized. It consists of a rounded plug that goes into the receiver and a plate that covers the back. Optionally, text can be put on the plate - it will be indented to the depth chosen. All parameters are settable, from the outside and inside of the plug, to the plate size and thickness.

I suggest printing this in PETG or, possibly ABS. If you want to put a political slogan on it and print it in PLA, that will likely work if the campaign is not too long.

I hope that it can be printed without supports or rafts, with the plate down. Consider white filament for the first three layers and then change to black - so that gives you black letters on a white sheet.

If you do not wish to have lettering, you can just turn it off.

Edit: The plate can now be other than square, it can be rectangular or oval (or square or circular) again, with or without lettering.

The plate should be accurately centered on the hitch cover. The variable "factor" controls the relative height to width, numbers lower than 1 mean that the plate is wider than it is tall, numbers higher than 1 mean that the plate is taller than it is wide. Use 1 to get a square or circular hitch cover. Again, all this stuff is parametric, just grab openSCAD

openSCAD - think of your project in shapes

This was all just a matter of positioning shapes and letters, so it was knocked out quickly in openSCAD. Rounding the plug was simple with a minkowski sum.

As usual for most of my objects, I expect to change it over the first few days. I expect to allow for a rectangular or oval plate, for one thing. This time I actually marked it as work in progress.

title: Electric Fidget Spinner Spinner (Fidget Spinner Engine/Motor)

description.text:
Motor in action: https://youtu.be/Y3K-K6oaDZE

You need a small button:
https://www.digikey.de/product-detail/de/wurth-electronics-inc/430182050816/732-7005-1-ND/5225453

A small cdrom engine with wires to the side like the one in the middle of this picture:
https://cdn.instructables.com/FLX/8N05/HYZX7I21/FLX8N05HYZX7I21.MEDIUM.jpg?width=614

two of those:
https://www.zamro.de/product/DB99D/knopfzelle-batterie-3v-170-mah-lithium-modell-cr2025

and two feathers from this kit:
https://www.amazon.de/dp/B00OBKF71M/ref=pe_386171_37038021_TE_3p_dp_1

Soldier a wire to the feather one, another wire two feather two.go with one to one pole of the engine. with the other to the button and then to the other pole of the motor.

Add both feathers in the battery tray, add the motor in the motor compartment, close it. add all covers. Then add the shell. use 10 or 16 mm m3 screws and on the other side m3 nuts (hope thats the right term)

Thing-O-Matic #5063, Makerbot. A robot barely alive. Gentlemen, we can rebuild him.
We have the technology.
We have the capability to build the world's first Fosterbot. Thing-o-Matic #5063 will be that Fosterbot. Better than it was before. Better, stronger, faster.

For the STL files:  Print in ABS, at least for the X-stage, if you are using a heated build platform.  Ounce of prevention and all that.
Pertinent info for the laser-cut panels:  These are formatted assuming a 24" x 48" sheet of 1/4" acrylic.  In the same way a f%&king 2x4 is not really 2" x 4", acrylic sheet that is nominally 1/4" thick is typically 5.5mm in thickness.  The interlocking features of the body panels are dimensioned for a sheet thickness of 5.5mm +/- 0.25mm.  Kerf from the laser cutting process may add an additional 0.1mm to that.  The formatting for the lines in the .dxf file is as follows:  Inside cuts in black, outside cuts in red.
Any purchased parts are referenced using McMaster-Carr part numbers, all of which have associated mechanical drawings and CAD files on their respective McMaster-Carr online catalog pages, in the event you would like to source material from elsewhere.  I'm not telling you where to buy you nuts, but those guys do carry everything.  They're like the ACME corporation from Looney Tunes.
While most of the machined parts can be made using a drill press and a bandsaw if you are patient and have a steady hand, the belt brackets will require a work-around if you do not have a milling machine.
For those of you feeling constrained by your build volume ever since the Replicator was released, these modifications increased my build envelope dimensions to 150mm on the x-axis, 185mm on the y-axis, and 132mm on the z-axis.  Also, between the linear bearing upgrade, the more rigid x-, y-, and z-stages, and Jetty's Accelerated Firmware v3.4, I've been printing at 100mm/s in ABS, and 150mm/s in PLA (and climbing).  Plus, she looks so damn sexy.
I had the panels laser-cut by NextFab Studio in Philadelphia (look them up, they're awesome).  Total cost was under $220, including the cost of acrylic sheeting.  I'm sure they can arrange shipping if you are not in the Philadelphia area.  Ponoko quoted me at $450, so this is definitely the price to beat.  I ordered everything from McMaster, and all told this upgrade cost ~$500.  If you shop around, you can probably shave a good chunk off of the that.
additional thoughts:
If you're making something from laser-cut acrylic, you need to get some Weld-On acrylic cement.  This stuff is awesome, but it is permanent.  So cement all of the body panels together without worry, but DO NOT CEMENT THE BOTTOM PANEL.  If your power supply or Y-axis stepper die, you won't be able to replace them.  More importantly, if you keep a desk lamp above your bot like I do, the cavity below the build platform will quickly fill up with dead bugs.

comments.text: I've made some improvements on this design in the past few months that I haven't gotten around to posting yet (not quite Fosterbot Beta - more like revision A03 at this point) so if you want any input, let me know. Â One really easy thing I've done to eke slightly higher XY resolution out of my bot is buying two of part # S10T08M016S0505 from Stock Drive Products/Sterling Instruments. Â It's a drop-in replacement pulley for the X- and Y- stepper motors on the T-O-M and they run about $10 each. Â The stock T-O-M pulleys have a pitch diameter of ~10.8mm, and these are 9.60mm. Â Your steps/mm goes up from ~47 to ~53, so you get slightly better positioning accuracy for $20.

description.text:
I reduced the diameter of the drive gear so that this fidget spinner is 60% zippier than my first Zippy Fidget Spinner! (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2379179)

It works great without the zip cord, too.

UPDATE: I've added a slightly smaller rip cord (zipper140.stl) for folks with a 150mm print bed.

https://youtu.be/ChEp8JVEj-4

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The part zippy2_.stl has a built-in break-away support where the bearing goes. Break this out and clean up any loose bits before proceeding with the assembly.

Assembly & Use

You'll need six 1/4-20 nuts (7/16" across the flats) for the inertial mass and one 608 bearing. After printing, press all 6 nuts into place in the outer ring (zippy.stl). Remove any shields or seals from your bearing and wash out any grease or oil to make it spin longer. Press the bearing into the outer ring so that it is flush with the bottom (the non-geared side). Insert the hub into the bearing so that it covers the gear. Press the hub cap into the other side of the hub. If it is not a tight fit, increase the size by 1% or so, or else carefully superglue in place.

After printing the zipper, run it under hot water and gently flex it so that it is more or less straight. Insert the end of the zipper into the slot in the hub and then let'r rip!

description.text:
I've remixed this super handy filament guide by ADVANCED3DCREATIONS https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1481508

This guide now includes a fan duct for a 40mm fan that blows air toward the hobbed bolt on the Dual V2 Tool head. I found that this helped mitigate the heat creep from reaching the hobbed bolt - which is one of the most critical flaws in this tool head. You can follow the install directions on the original thing. I had to add a longer screw and nut to help make sure that this mounted nicely. I also cut a slot out on the right side to make the screw hole easier to access with a screwdriver or pliers. Enjoy!

title: Blue Origin New Shepard
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a model of Blue Origin's New Shepard rocket, one of the first rockets to successfully land and relaunch it's first stage. The model has the following features:

•Rotate the engine to raise and lower the landing legs
•Removable crew capsule
•Drag flaps that can be opened and closed
•Upper fins that fold in for launch and out for landing
•Rotatable lower fins
•Display stand

Images of the actual rocket can be found here: https://www.blueorigin.com/gallery

Printing Notes:
Be very careful when removing support material, especially from the lower stage as it is easy to snap the leg struts before the landing legs are attached.
Grasp the landing struts by the hinge when first rotating them to avoid snapping them.

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/sxZMENbvm_c&feature=youtu.be" ></iframe>
Landing leg mechanism: the files have been since modified prevent the jamming seen in the video

Images for each step below.

  1. Attach the landing legs to the lower stage by sliding the struts into one side of the leg and snapping the other side into place.

  2. With the legs in the lowered position, screw the gear about half way into the lower stage with the smaller diameter end down. Glue the engine onto the gear post sticking through the bottom of the lower stage. (Super glue works well)

  3. Place the middle stage on top of the lower stage with the slots facing down and lined up with the landing legs. Turn the engine so that the wide part at the top of the gear is resting against the plate in the middle of the middle stage.

  4. Place some glue on the inside of the gear cap and place it on top of the gear through the top of the middle stage. Once the glue dries you should be able to twist the engine to raise and lower the landing gear. **DO NOT glue the cap to the middle stage. It needs to be able to rotate freely when the gear is turned.

  5. Glue the upper stage onto the middle stage, lining up the ridges on the sides of the rocket.

  6. Glue the ring adaptor to the top of the upper stage.

  7. Insert the ring fins into the slots on the ring adaptor with the longer flat end on the bottom.

  8. Insert the lower fins into the holes between the legs on the lower stage.
Step 1. Step 2 Step 3 Step 4

Expand your Z-axis! The fine folk at 4DM let you expand X and Y, but here it is for Z!

This was developed with the help of gingger.

This kit includes a 35mm and 25mm lift. The 25mm lift is a little less involved but installs basically the same.

PRINTABLE FILES

The 35mm kit has two spacers, one just a block and one with a 30mm fan mount to keep the Z-axis motor cool. This motor is usually in a holding condition and gets quite warm. I will likely be adding more spacers later for other accessories.

Motor spacer is for 35mm kit only.

Each kit has 4 available Z switch mounts. The X5+0 ones are for printing on tape or similar. If you have glass, the X5+1, X5+2, X5+3 ones are offsets for glass. Print the one closest to your glass thickness and adjust the rest with the bed screws.

If you have a 6mm gantry support rod, I suggest this one instead. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2393720

PLEASE READ BEFORE INSTALLING

Rear tower cover will need to be modified or removed.
X-axis gantry cover must be removed. You will need something like this for the X-axis switch unless you have a very early V1: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1761961

If you prefer a video for instructions instead of my terrible pictures, here's a nice YouTube tutorial by lightofhonor: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P1TH-9Q3Qlk

Parts:

For the 35mm kit, you will need:
(4)35mm M-F hex standoffs.
(2)10mm M-F hex standoffs.
(2)M3 nuts.
Longer bowden tube.
-Printed parts-
Main Spacer.
Motor Spacer.
Appropriate Z switch mount

For the 25mm kit, you will need:
(4)25mm M-F hex standoffs.
(2)M3 nuts.
Longer bowden tube.
-Printed parts-
Main Spacer.
Appropriate Z switch mount

If you're doing this on a V1, you'll need some nuts for the Z-switch screws. I didn't include that particular issue in the pictures because on the V2, the screws don't thread into the tower and you already have the nuts.

You may need to extend your hotend wiring. The stock stuff on my V2 would reach with a 35mm kit, but just barely. If you have a 4DM Brutus bed, it will certainly not reach.

Installation would also benefit from an additional M3 nut and a lock washed on top of each main standoff. These aren't the strongest threads and I don't trust them. You'll see them in the pics.

Note that installing this will require you to remove or modify your rear tower panel. The bottom tab on the panel prevents the X-axis gantry from going lower. The tower is still plenty stable without the rear cover attached as long as you have the front one. If you're using the awesome adjustable Z-axis limit switch mount, unfortunately you won't be able to anymore as it sits on that tab.

You don't need to get these parts, just where I got mine. Another note: in the pictures, I have 25mm standoffs threaded with 8mm ones. Not ideal, but still waiting on parts and it's what I had. I didn't want you guys waiting for another month while I waited on parts.

35mm standoffs: http://www.ebay.com/itm/322324440854?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
25mm standoffs: http://www.ebay.com/itm/322121559859?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&var=511043842658&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
10mm standoffs: http://www.ebay.com/itm/352023976895?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
I got my nuts, lock washers, and a ton of other M3 stuff here: http://www.ebay.com/sch/m.html?_odkw=&_ssn=rivercityindustrialsupply&_armrs=1&_osacat=0&_from=R40&_trksid=p2046732.m570.l1313.TR10.TRC2.A0.H0.XM3.TRS2&_nkw=M3&_sacat=0
(I like to buy in bulk)

Instructions

Unless you don't mind messing with your Z coupler, I recommend you tell your printer to put the X-axis gantry up as high as it can go. Doing it by hand like I did is a pain.

I did these with the intent of a 35mm kit and not putting the rear panel back on.

STEP ONE: Remove your side panels, connectors, and bottom panel. If you need me to tell you how to do this, this mod is not for you.

STEP TWO: Remove the 4 screws holding the tower to the base, and pull off.

STEP THREE: Remove the 6 screws on bottom, and 6 screws on top holding the tower panels off, and set the panels aside. Also remove the two screws holding the Z motor in.

STEP FOUR: Turn the Z threaded rod to remove it from the X-gantry, or decouple. I prefer not to mess with the couplers if I don't have to.

STEP FIVE: Add the main standoffs into the screw holes used to attach the tower to the gantry. Also install the two 10mm standoffs into the holes for the motor.
!25mm kit does not need the motor standoffs.

STEP SIX: Remove your Z limit switch from the tower and mount it to your new bracket. Slide your bracket onto the standoffs for the motor, or the motor screws for the 25mm kit. Install the nuts to keep it in place. If you're doing the 25mm kit, you may need some longer screws.

Install lock washers and nuts on the standoffs to keep them in place if you'd like.

STEP SEVEN: Only for 35mm kit. Slide the motor spacer over the standoffs. The standoffs themselve might be good enough, but I think the spacer will help keep it stable.

STEP EIGHT: Re-install your motor. Note in the picture I had it backwards. Do it correctly. This is also a good time to re-install your front cover. It will be a pain after you get the tower on the base.

STEP NINE: Slide your spacer over the standoffs. The size stamp on the space is the top. Also note I have installed a 30mm fan since I had a spare fan for my hotends sitting around.

STEP TEN: Feed your cables through the hole of the tower and re-install the 4 mounting screws into the standoffs. Reassemble the printer as normal.

STEP ELEVEN: Level your bed like you normally would. The only other change you should need to do is the Z size in your slicer. However, if you have the X gantry all the way up and tell the printer to home, it will time out before it reaches the switch. Don't worry if it stops, just tell it to home again.
!If you start a print with it all the way up and rely on the start gcode to home it, it will not care that it never actually homed and it will start the print in mid air. I'm modifying my start gcode to home twice so I don't do this again..

If you make this, please upload a make. I'd like to verify it's working across the generations. Also any problem PLEASE let me know and I'll try to make some adjustments.

If you like this, please check out my other things!

comments.text: I wanna say 0.175mm layer, 3 shells, 6 Top / Bottom layers and 25% cubic infill.
comments.author: Grim90

comments.text: Hi, Sorry just checking, is that 3mm thick shells and 6mm top and bottom? That's a lot of plastic :-) I'm building without the fan I was thinking 3mm top/bottom and 1.6mm shells. Thanks.
comments.author: Geonovast

comments.text: Oh no lol.  3 shells (walls) would be the three passes.  With a .4mm nozzle, that would be 1.2mm. 6 Top/bottom layers is just that - number of layers.  So the top and bottom layers would be 1.05mm thick (6 x 0.175).  And my settings are probably overkill, considering the printed piece isn't even required for the mod, all you need is the standoffs.  The printed part is just to add some stability.
comments.author: Konkonkaos

comments.text: Thank you. Remember you're talking to one of the great unwashed here :-) . I'm using Cura and can set wall thickness by mm not passes (at lest in the settings I cold find). Also I'm not sure a 0.4mm dia nozzle gives you a 0.4mm wide print pass, firstly the tip squishes the 0.4mm dia feed into 0.1mm high, so mathematically I would have assumed it actually printed a bit wider, but that would also depend on the feed speed I guess. Keen to understand this more. None the less I'll stick in the mm and go with that. Cheers.
comments.author: Geonovast

comments.text: Understood, I was insanely green when I got my first printer.  Typically you set your wall thickness to multiples of your nozzle diameter.
comments.author: Konkonkaos

comments.text: Thank you
comments.author: Geonovast

comments.text: I plan to start printing this tomorrow. I just need to replace my hotend tip and oil cure it before hand. I'm also planning on installing the Brutus from 4D in November
comments.author: Choku

comments.text: Definitely extend your hotend wiring while you're in there.  The lift plus Brutus will need longer wires.
comments.author: Choku

comments.text: Firstly thanks for sharing and providing a very 2 solution. I'm about to do a Brutus kit install and thought why not go taller? Wiring is easy, surely it's just longer linear rods and a screw shaft? All cheap parts. Or am I missing something?
comments.author: Geonovast

comments.text: Actually, you don't need longer linear rods or a lead screw for the Z axis.  This mod works by adding a spacer between the base and tower, which lets the X-axis carriage do down lower than before.  All you're going to need is some M3 standoffs of the same length you make your spacer.  Since you're doing this and a Brutus, is it safe to assume you're also doing the NEMA/8mm Lead screw mod?  If you take a tower cover off with it stock, and home the Z axis, you'll see that there's a little bit more than 35mm of room left on the rods for the carriage to go down!  What's stopping it is the switch and bed.  This mod just utilizes that space.
comments.author: Konkonkaos

title: 12 Volt Power Supply Cover - Remixed v2

Changes:

v2:

  1. Added a hole to fit a C14 power socket (used one I removed from a Dell PSU);
  2. made it taller, so cables can fit better inside the cover;
  3. added 2mm holes for optional screws.

title: Anet A6/A8 Extruder Heatsink Fan Spacer/Support Upgrade

description.text:
In the Anet A6 kit the 40mm fan is bolted against the cooling rib to keep the filament assembly drive together. This is done without no support for the fan.

I made this spacer/standoff design to give proper support for the 40mm cooling fan and make the assembly more rigid. To make assembly easier the two spacers is interconnected with a bridge with correct spacing, just insert it into the cooling rib as shown on the photos.

description.text:
I designed a simple little switch mount that easily fastens to aluminum extrusion with M3 T-nuts. It has a gap between the switch and whatever it is mounted to so that wires can be routed through. The mount is compatible with these switches:
https://www.amazon.com/Support-Car-Round-Toggle-Switch/dp/B00RXCOCSY/ref=sr_1_1?s=automotive&ie=UTF8&qid=1497565617&sr=1-1-spons&keywords=e+support+toggle+switch&psc=1

This mount should also work with acrylic frames that have long enough screws to pass through both the mount and the frame (such as Anet A6 and A8).

author: jantzenday

description.text:
iPhone 6 / 6S case with a fidget spinner knob on the back. Works with a standard bearing that attaches to the case with a plug, and then a wheel snaps onto the bearing. The wheel has a slot for a 1/8" bungee to go through that you can put your finger in to easily hold your phone - knot bungee from inside before putting around bearing.

A layer of smooth paper can help reduce friction between the case and the wheel. Shimming the plug and bearing will help if the fit is loose.

Customized from attributed model

the attributed source included an SCAD file. using Open SCAD, i adjusted the text, font, and font size. I considered turning the hex openings into bearing openings as well, but decided to leave those as they are.
this print intentionally runs the text into the hex nut openings. it works well without the hex nuts at this fill level, but modifying it to smaller text will allow those to be filled. The text is also raised above the hex nut openings, so the text inside the opening can be trimmed away with a small amount left above it that will overlap on top of the hext nut and preserve the visible lettering.

author: QuejoPrint

print_settings.Notes:: The tires must be printed in TPU or they will not fit onto the rims. If your slicer can process intersecting models, import the tire and rim on top of each other to avoid this and print the wheels as a single part.

description.text:
This is a fully 3D-Printable "body-on-frame" pickup truck that rolls like any other toy car. There are no bearings, screws, nuts, washers, or any other metal "helpers" involved. It prints entirely without supports (if you have your print settings dialed in), and it assembles by friction fit. You can glue it together if you like, but it is not required.

It is intended to be a CO2 powered rocket car, but I have not yet figured out how to open a 12-gram CO2 canister while it sits in the bed of the truck. I use electrical tape to hold the tailgate on and ensure that the cartridge does not "go rogue" during tests; this is what you can see in the pictures. If anyone prints this and figures out a better solution to launching this than free-handing it with a Dremel cut-off wheel, let me know.

Nonetheless, it is a pretty nice toy car, even if I can't blast it down the street with compressed air just yet. It rolls down inclines fairly straight when assembled properly, and it crashes nicely with pieces flying everywhere, provided it hasn't been glued together.

This is going to take you anywhere from 12 to 32 hours to print, depending on print speed, layer height, and how many body panels fail unexpectedly on you. I don't imagine this will be easy to print for a lot of printers, so be patient and take it one piece at a time.

Speaking of which, here is the bill of materials with part summaries:

1 x Pickup Frame
This can be one of the four permutations. There are varieties with and without supports, and UNTESTED hollow versions as well. I have not printed and tested the fit of the hollow frame to the matching roof, so should you try this, it may require sanding or packing of some sort.

1 x Roof OR Press Fit Roof
The normal roof has holes for the pins that mount it to the frame. The press fit roof has a rectangular piece that is meant to press-fit in the hollow frame; again, I have not tested it.

1 x Hood and Grille
This piece has my signature headlight and grille pattern that I doubt you've seen before. Seriously, tell me where you've seen it before. Nowhere. That's right.

1 x Doors
The doors wrap around the back of the cab and are pinned on either side.

1 x Pickup Bed
The bed has a round holder for the closed end of a 12g CO2 cartridge. With the tailgate piece and some tape, this should hold it fairly safely and securely.

1 x Tailgate
This has a hole for the open end of a 12g CO2 cartridge. Don't trust the taper pins; use tape.

1 x Right Fender
1 x Left Fender
1 x Right Quarterpanel
1 x Left Quarterpanel
These pieces go over the wheels to protect the undercarriage, but really they just help to make the truck look like a truck.

18 OR 20 x Diamond Taper Pin
These pins hold the whole truck together. They don't hold very well. That's entirely on purpose. If you squeeze them in nice and tight, they friction fit just well enough that you can handle the truck normally, but pop out when you want to change a body panel. This friction fit also means that when the truck crashes, the pieces come off in a spectacular show. They also make excellent locator pins for gluing, if rigidity is your thing. (20 for full, 18 for hollow)

2 x Axle Support
These pieces snap into the bottom of the frame to connect the axles. They should just pop in and out of their sockets satisfyingly, but they will wear out with repeated use.

2 x Pickup Axle
These axles are octagonal to allow them to print on our machines. Most of the things that get press fit onto them will still be circles. Be sure to sand or cut off the build plate burr.

2 x Inner Bushing
This bushing is press-fit onto the axle to act as a "bearing" that allows the wheels to spin. Its inner diameter may or may not need to be drilled/sanded to fit nicely on the axle.

2 x Outer Bushing
This bushing is press-fit into the axle support to allow the wheels to spin. Make sure it doesn't deform when pressed in or your axle will not spin true.

4 OR 8 x Bushing Nut.
These are used to keep the axle centered on the axle support. If you plan on gluing, you only need 4 (or 0, perhaps). If you want the friction fit to work, I recommend printing 8.

4 x Pickup Wheel
These are my custom 6-spoke wheels. They are lipped on either end to retain tires.

4 x Pickup Tire
THESE MUST BE PRINTED IN TPU. I used SainSmart TPU. Comment if you need the settings for this filament. If you don't have TPU or a printer that can print with it, I would suggest importing the wheel and tire into your slicer directly on top of each other and printing as one piece. I can't be sure how this will affect the truck's performance, however.

I believe that's it. Good luck with the project, now you have an excuse to try out TPU. Leave a comment with any questions or requests. This is a work in progress, so I have all the files ready for modification and re-posting. Thanks for checking out my Magnum Opus to date!

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm - .3mm

Infill:

5%-100%

Notes:

This truck was sized to a 12g CO2 canister and the build volume of my FlashForge Creator Pro. I imagine it could size down alright to maybe 75%, but I have no conjectures past that.

Make sure small structural parts (axles, bushings, wheels, pins, etc.) are printed at 100% infill for strength and weight.

The body panels should be printed with two shells at 100%, gap fill for extra strength optional. I printed those and the pins with ABS for strength, but PLA will be fine.

The frame can be anywhere from 5% to 15% infill, but I recommend three shells to support the diamond pin holes. It will take a long time. I printed this with AMZ3D black PLA overnight and had no issues, but I was super confident with that filament. I didn't need a raft, but I imagine many people will.

The tires must be printed in TPU or they will not fit onto the rims. If your slicer can process intersecting models, import the tire and rim on top of each other to avoid this and print the wheels as a single part.

I started by designing the body shape of a pickup truck and shelling it out. Then, I used that shell to start a frame, which I then edited further to save print time and plastic. I cut out some windows, then I split the body shape into panels and found on two suitable, non-intersecting fastener points for each one.

Next, I developed a diamond-shaped friction-based fastener that prints easily. The hole for this fastener can be printed into a model in any orientation: top, bottom, or side. This allows for standardization across the whole model.

I designed the wheels and tires after the body was done. I used circular patterns to my advantage when designing these, but overall, they are relatively simple parts. The round hole in the wheel fits the axle quite well and the TPU tires hug the wheels nicely.

Then I hatched the idea of octagonal axles with round, vertically-printed bushings. This makes printing a breeze, while still allowing the truck to roll as a vehicle should. The bushing nuts on the outside keep all of this centered without looking out of place.

At this point, I had axles with wheels in one hand and a paneled frame on the other. The last part I designed was the axle support. This round-topped part snaps into the body tightly and holds the outer bushing for the axle, bringing the two halves together. The hole for the bushing is pointed at the top to allow for no-issue printing without supports. This part truly was the crux of the whole project.

description.text:
This is a puzzle I have since maybe 30 years ago.
I have searched and seems like nobody have it anymore and the customizable models don´t do it the way I wanted it.
In the first picture you can see th original puzzle, so you can compare the results.
At first, I tried to make it from a coustomizable rubiks found here, with no good results, so I´ve modified several parts in order to fit good.
This is not a speed model, so be carefull.
It is a work in progress, so I´ll try to impove it in several ways; i.e. minimize friction so the motion be better.

Pieces needed:

1 Core (RC_CoreJC02)
6 Centers (RC_center01)
6 Plugs (Plugs05)
8 Corner pieces. (RC_corner01A) or (RC_corner02D)
12 Edges (RC_Edge01)

For the corners, there are two files:

  1. The first is the piece (RC_corner01A). If you have you printer fully optimized, you can print it them easily.
  2. And the other (RC_corner02D) has a little support in some difficult places that the slicer programs don´t consider as support needed.
    Those parts are marked in red in one picture, and it says "remove this part".

You will also need six 3mm bolts and 3mm springs. They go inside the center parts. So the rotations comes good.
The holes in the center parts can be cover by stikers or with the little plugs included. (6 of them, I printed them hollow).

The core and the edge pieces are better printed with supports.

I will update with special stickers and different geometric motives.

Any comments will be wellcome.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

10

Notes:

UPDATE # 1.

Stickers for the puzzle.

I´ve uploaded a pdf file with the stickers that you can use with this puzzle.

Also, there are two pictures that shows how should it be the perfect geometry.

Have fun with them.

description.text:
This is a bracket to let you put a flexion extruder on your CR-10. Make sure you have a pass through coupler for the bowden tube so the tube makes contact with the flexion. That is what stops the filament from bending and escaping the extruder.

this is what I use:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01IB81IHG

But any cupler that can do a pass through of the tube should work

To make sure the tube is correctly in place, you should cut an angle (60°) on the PTFE tube that goes against the Flexion drive unit. It should be pushed against the nip point with the cam on position 4.

A cheap & dirty derivative of Finger Wheel that puts the 5/16" hex nut recess in the face of the wheel and uses the collar as a coupler to a 1/4" stepper shaft.
Printed on a SeeMeCNC H1 with 45% infill.

If you don't happen to have a dual shaft stepper and still want manual control on a constrained (Z) axis, this shaft coupler adds a fingerwheel between the stepper and 5/16" rod.  
Mount the motor using 2" hex bolts, the fingerwheel is narrower than the mounting holes for a NEMA23.

description.text:
This is a customization of www.thingiverse.com/thing:1849269. The original one was off balance and the bearing holes were too small. So I had to recreate it with Solidworks and fix it. This one is perfectly balanced.

I have included an adapter to use a 17mm x 6mm x 6mm bearing, I found some ceramic ball hybrid bearings that make this thing spinner for a long time. Here is a link.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06Y2HH6Z7/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

So you can use the 608 22mm x 8mm by 8mm or the 17mm in the center, then just use the 608 on the ends for weight.

I have also included Grip caps and flat caps for each size bearing. Flat caps for use in the outer 2 bearings and Grip caps in the center

Installing the bearings: I use a small Arbor Press, but a vise will also work. Also I use a socket that is exactly the size of of the outer ring of the bearing. Just remember to press the bearings and adapter in slowly so as not to crack the plastic.

First things first: this was inspired by this tap handle and it was created in OnShape before I realized that the other model included the part file...

This model is different because:

  • It does not require any support material
  • There is just enough threading to allow for stability while tightly fitting to a 3/8" screw
  • It requires less material as it is thinner (20% infill gives it more than enough strength)
  • The fillets on the top and bottom are of different radii to allow for a different finished look

The current stl is threaded for a 3/8"-16 Tap.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with Simplify3d, but I'm sure it will print just fine on any slicer software.  You can print it at 0.1mm layer height, but it makes the end too thick unless you play a reed hardness of 4 on the Vandoren ratings.

description.text:
After printing the original Mk1 Tenor Reed from the Saxophone & Clarinet Reeds by wierd101, I realized my printer could print it much thinner, and much easier to play. The original was 0.25mm at the tip, and my cane reeds are about 0.1mm at the tip.

This thing plays like a dream... I already own a couple of Legere reeds, and this one feels just as smooth, and sounds great... Enjoy it all you tenor players with 3d printers... wait, is that a thing?

Printer:

MakerFarm Pegasus 12"

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.050mm

Infill:

20%-100% depending on rigidity

Notes:

Printed with Simplify3d, but I'm sure it will print just fine on any slicer software. You can print it at 0.1mm layer height, but it makes the end too thick unless you play a reed hardness of 4 on the Vandoren ratings.

You may still need to do a bit of fine sanding... you can get the layer lines to completely disappear with a quick run of 180 on the cane end, followed by 400 all over, and 900-1000 to finish.

Only sand from the top, as sanding the bottom will change the way it lays on your mouthpiece, just like a cane reed.

I tinkered the original to only 0.1mm thick, stretched the z measurement to 3.5mm to match a Vandoren Java 2 1/2, and printed it at 0.050mm layer height with 10 borders, 2 top layers and 2 bottom layers on a MakerFarm Pegasus 12. The minimum layer height of this printer is rated at 50 microns, but this thing printed so perfectly, I might print it again at 0.020mm layer height just for fun.

comments.text: What type of filament are you using to print your reeds?  I play alto, tenor, and bari sax and the cost of reeds (cane or Legere) is just going up and up.  Want to try this but not sure what type of filament to use.  Thanks in advance!

description.text:
This is a simple open case designed to be used with the Black Magic Probe v2.1 by 1BitSquared. (https://1bitsquared.com/products/black-magic-probe). This version has small fins to protect the JTAG connector.

I wanted to add a little protection while using it on my crowded desk or in general handling. The fins and stripe won't really make it go faster.

There are small tabs that hold the corners of the circuit board in place. Tilt the board and insert the USB-connector end of the board into the shallow end of the case first. Then slide the other end down, spread the sides of the case apart as needed until the board snaps in place under the tabs. Of course, be extremely careful not to put pressure on any components on the board!

title: Riding Wolf for small D&D; figures

description.text:
Fits small-sized miniatures (20mm bases or less). Requires glue.

Edits to the original (beyond cutting out the riding portion):
Shrunk to 90%. (Still a bit tall, but not as tall as a riding horse.)
Cleaned up the base, attached back feet.
Cut it in half, so the support scars would be on the inside of the legs.

Similar to my horse for D&D figures https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1844378

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm layer height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The support can be touching buildplate only, if you're using Cura — should only put supports between the legs and the buildplate.

Blender

Imported into Blender. Created a cone+cylinder to cut out the riding figure, extended it to flat in the back to make it easier to insert/remove figure. Created a cylinder/disc for the figure to stand on.

Stretched out the hind legs so they would touch the base. Subdivided the base edge to give it a rounder shape, then narrowed it to an oval. Reduced the base's thickness.

Sliced it in half, by creating a large cube to contain the wolf, then subdividing it vertically. Selected one half of the large cube, and "P" allows you to separate the selection of an object into a new object. (You'll need to add internal faces to each half.) For those two blocks, boolean intersection with the wolf model (carve).

author: bipsen

title: Dual bearing X-idler seat extension for the German RepRap x400

description.text:
The original German RepRap x400 comes with 3D printed sintered plastic X and Y carriages. The X direction idler pulley sits in the Y-carriage in a cantilever fashion attached to a 608zz bearing using a shoulder bolt. The tension on the X-belt causes a deflection of the idler's axis, therefore grinding into the belt. This must be an oversight in the original otherwise good overall design of this 3D printer. There is also nothing stopping the bearing from sliding out of the 10mm thick seat other than mild friction and the X-belt tension.

This seat extension solves all the above problems by including a second 608zz bearing, keeping the axis straight under loading with proper constraint of the whole assembly.

Instructions and extra components

4x M3x40mm Socket Head Screws
8x M3 washers (optional)
4x M3 Nylock Nuts
1x M6x61 Socket Head Shoulder Screw
1x 608ZZ ball bearing

Print the part and ream the bolt holes to size using a 3mm drill bit.
Before going further, you might want to consider adding a belt tightening solution, as it is not easy to put back the belts in place tight enough after removing the belt caps from the back of the extruder motor mount. You can download my belt tightening caps for the X and Y carriages (links here).

Untighten the X-belt and disassemble the idler/bearing/shoulder screw.
Press the new 608ZZ bearing inside the printed seat and assemble the whole thing as shown in the picture, with the same washers in place. Bolt the assembly in place using the M3 bolts, washers and Nylocks. Don't tighten the idler's M6 Nylock too much as this will cause the sides of the bearings to lock up. To get rid of the slack, gently tighten first, then unscrew 1/4 turn or until the bearing rotate freely.

Even though this configuration is also cantilever, now the bending moment is properly supported by two distant bearings, keeping the idler's axis straight.

Enjoy!

author: mrtayters

description.text:
Just got a Nintendo Switch recently and came up with a idea of putting the console (w/ Joy Con removed) into a 3D printed cabinet. Should look cool especially with Street Fighter or KoF series.

The whole thing is designed in SketchUp and parts are separated for easy printing. You can adjust the wordings on the top cover ("Nintendo") to something else you like. I've uploaded the source file so in case you would like to redesign the DPad to a Joystick.

Assembly notes:

  1. Adjust the length of the support beam, top cover and keypad if you face tolerance issue. Should be fairly easy. (i.e.: You can use it for other screen with similar size)
  2. Assemble the beams and Dpad first by gluing or cold wielding (PLA wielding), followed by the side plate
  3. Slide in the Nintendo Switch with Joy Con removed
  4. Plug in charger cable if needed
  5. Cover the top plate (DO NOT GLUE)
    And enjoy!!!

Updates

2017_06_29: Photos uploaded! Ran out of filament so the prototype is all white (Epic fail)
2017_06_20: Rev.2 Support beam updated. Added in glue reservoir for better gluing effect (In case you don't use PLA cold wielding)
2017_06_16: Rev.1 Assembly reference model uploaded. Please do not print it.
I'm still printing the model, will upload photos once it is ready.

UPDATE Feb 16, 2018: Added zipped marlin files configured for BlueRAHM. This configuration uses standard RAMPS 14 connections with 2 exceptions. Second endstop connector used for right side Z endstop and Left side Z motor is connected to Extruder 2.

UPDATE Feb 14, 2018: Added 2 pictures of endstop assemblies. Corrected X endstop part labels.

UPDATE October 28, 2017: Replaced part L1 due to missing face.

UPDATE October 2017: Added improved door: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2578498/#files with assembly instructions.

UPDATE September 2017: Added photos of completed units. Will add upgrade for top and door later.

UPDATE July 4, 2017: Revised parts Y2, Z3, Z4 to provide clearance.

UPDATE July 4, 2017: Revised part ZH to allow belt clearance.

UPDATE July 3, 2017: Revised parts Z1, Z2, B5, B8. Improved access to Z rod clamp screw and remove unneeded access hole on B5 and B8.

UPDATE June 28, 2017: Revised parts YA and Z10.

UPDATE June 26, 2017: Designed Z axis extension kit. Thing: 240611. ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2406116)

Mostly Printed 3D Printer Optimized to Print ABS. The XY mechanism is of my own devising and as far as I can find it is brand new. It is a combination of ideas taken from the Ultimaker gantry and Richard Horne's Sli3dr Printer but I believe better and simpler than either.

3D Printer Features:
Features Genuine or clone E3D V6 hotend and graphic controller at $350 price point.
Modular construction. Size can be adjusted by adding or removing modules.
More area inside printer is usable as print area compared to many other designs.
All motors outside of build area to allow heated chamber.
Integrated cable management for clean look.
Nearly all parts 3D printed, easily enclosed for printing ABS.
Features horizontal drag chain and low profile cover.
Innovative XY mechanism with excellent accuracy and low parts cost.
XY uses belts and LM8UU bearings.
Can use bowden or direct extruder (this version uses bowden).

Videos: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NaFrrTMu-uQ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DYeEHxprvno

Orientation of parts and settings for printing is left to the user. Most parts do not require support but a few do. Refer to parts list, included jpeg. The settings I used required about 4kg of ABS. I generally pay about $20 canadian per kg.

Currently a work in progress. More assembly instructions and pictures will follow. Parts for top are not included yet and hardware parts list has not been done. No assembly instructions currently so I suggest you not attempt this printer unless you are handy. Please let me know if you find errors. If you would like to see build instruction videos and hood/enclosure design, let me know. This is a work in progress.

comments.text: Drag chain links are held together with pieces of filament 1.75mm. Heat end with lighter. Pass through hole. Cut flush plus a few milimeters. Message me if you would like me to send you a copy of marlin already configured.

title: Tronxy X1 radial fan mount and nozzle.

description.text:
Update 2: I had too much trouble with hotend cooling with this bundle. I have moved on to an alternate configuration which is working weel for me. I no longer recommend this bundle.

This is just a bundling of a 50mm radial fan mount and a nozzle that worked together for me on the tronxy x1. It's a simple mount without replacing all the bits. note: I made none of this. All credit goes to:

it's the mount from FabianFriethjoph https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2330698/#files

and the nozzle from louiscooper https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2184575

Also I had the idea for a bundled remix thing, and wanted to see if thingiverse supported dual remix.

Update:
my experience with this combo so far is that the part cooling fan and duct manage to cool my hotend too much. when the fan turns on high the temp drops by 15° C and struggles to come back up. on the tronxy x1 with dead-time based heat management. I switched to PID management and tuned PID with the fan on high, this worked but I think is a bit of a hack work around. and the PID heat management oscillates when the fan is not on high. an alternative approach is to keep the fan speed low in your slicer.

I will probably try other arrangements next.

title: Adjustable height E3D V6 nozzle seat for dual nozzle 3D printers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Adjusting the nozzle height on some dual nozzle printer rely solely on the accuracy of the components. One such printer is the German RepRap X400. There is no easy way of setting both nozzle's height correctly.

This nozzle seat solves this problem with a linear cam height adjustment mechanism embedded inside the nozzle's clamp. This clamp aligns the nozzle with the MK8 hobbed gear. Together with the push lever, this is a revised extruder for the X400, but will work with most direct drive extruders. It provides a height adjustment of about 2.40mm.

UPDATE:
More elegant design without the screw cap. Now the screw is fully contained in the block. Tightening screw for the nozzle added to fully secure it in place.

UPDATE 2:
Use the vernier patterns to calculate the nozzle offsets down to 0.1mm.

BOM and Instructions

Push Lever:
Print on the top surface (0.2mm layer is fine)
1x M4x12 socket head screw
1x 25mm spacer (OD 4.76mm, ID 3.6mm)
1x 13x4x5 ball-bearing
1x M3x30 socket screw
1x M3 washer
2x M3 oversized washers
1x M3x60 socket head screw
1x M3 nut
1x 10 turn spring (OD 10mm, uncompressed length 30mm) or shorter stiffer spring

Adjustable height clamp:
Print these parts with 0.1mm layer height for accuracy. No supports needed. A brim of 10 lines will help adhesion and prevent ABS from warping.
Print the halves on their sides, with the cavities upward.
Print the key on its ramp, the square slot pointing up.
Print the lift ramp flat on the spring hole surface.
Print the screw cap on its front flat.
1x M3x20 socket head screw
1x M3x15 socket head screw
2x M3 square nut
4x M2x10 socket head screws
1x print bed spring (OD 4.8mm, L 7mm)
2x M3x30 socket head screws
2x M3 washers
1x paperclip

Clean up the printed parts and file the mating surfaces, mainly the key and the lift ramp surfaces. Ream all holes to their sizes with drill bits, except for the 4 2mm holes in the front half of the clamp, these will be self-tapped by the M2 screws when closing the screw cap.
Press the square nut in the middle of the key in the slot provided. Careful not to break the key, not much tolerance there.
Assemble the front part of the clamp by capturing the head of the M3 socket head screw (adjustment screw), threads towards the inside, with the screw cap and the 4 M2 screws. You'll have to self-tap the screws in. This is my solution in the absence of a proper retaining ring screw!
Thread the key on the adjustment screw all the way in, with the square nut facing the bottom of the clamp (ramp facing up the cavity).
Place the E3D heat sink in the clamp along with the lift ramp, with the ramp pointing downwards.
Place the spring in the cavity provided with a little compression.
Close the other half, making sure that the spring is contained.
Attach the nozzle and heating block as per E3D instructions.
Bolt the assembly to the NEMA17 motor using the two M3x30 bolts, don't tighten fully yet.
Using an Allen key, adjust the height of the nozzle. A counter clockwise turn will push the key under the ramp, thus raising the height of the nozzle. A clockwise turn will pull the key, and lower the nozzle, thanks to the spring. Once the nozzle's height is set, tighten the bolts.

UPDATE:
The height adjustment screw is now retained with a paperclip passed through the provided holes.
Tightening screw with captive square nut pushes the piston against the heat sink's collar.

Make adjustments with the tightening screw loose, then tighten gently just enough to keep the heat sink rotating and wobbling.

Enjoy!

print_settings.Notes:: This was designed to be a decorative model and is not strong enough without modifications to be used for cosplay or anything else.

description.text: A Witcher's silver sword I modeled based off the one used by Geralt in the Witcher 3. The dimensions are nearly identical to the ones mentioned in the books (12" hilt, 27.75" blade). I plan to upload another version later with additional detail on the model including the runes you see etched on the side in the game.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

15%

Notes:

This was designed to be a decorative model and is not strong enough without modifications to be used for cosplay or anything else.

I roughed the edges of each section with sandpaper and used Loctite Gel Control super glue to connect the pieces. After that I used a filler on any gaps and sanded them down. I used three different color Rustoleum paint + primer spray paints for the components which gave it a metallic look.
I used google sketch up and modeled it after pictures. Dimensions were taken from the books and by eye, based off the models used in game.

I have a large selection of cameras and I love to use them. Now I can just let this dice roll and let it decide for me. Each icon can be made to represent a camera or type of cameras you own. Since I like using all of them I would go with what the random choice picks. It brings a little bit of RPG to real life :)

I used MODO to make this.
